theorem.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 (FTC1)
theorem.p: If f is continuous on [a,b], then the function g defined by g(x) = \ds \int_a^x f(t)\, dt, for a\leq x\leq b is continuous on [a,b], differentiable on (a,b), and g'(x) = f(x). Using Leibniz notation, we have \ds \dfrac{d}{dx}\left[\int_a^x f(t)\, dt\right] = f(x)

theorem.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 (FTC2)
theorem.p: If f is continuous on [a,b], then \ds \int_a^b f(x)\, dx = F(b)-F(a), where F is any antiderivative of f.
